steps.name: Given that the Entando Operator is running in 'Red Hat' compliance mode
And the Operator runs in a Kubernetes environment the requires a filesystem user/group override for mounted volumes
And the routing suffix has been configured globally
And a TLS Secret was created and configured as default
And there is a controller to process requests for the DBMS capability
And there is a controller to process requests for the SSO capability
When I create an EntandoApp with minimal configuration
Executing command PROVIDE_CAPABILITY
with the DBMS service 'default-postgresql-dbms-in-namespace-service'
and the admin secret 'default-postgresql-dbms-in-namespace-admin-secret'
Executing command PROVIDE_CAPABILITY
with the SSO service 'default-sso-in-namespace-service'
and the admin secret 'default-sso-in-namespace-admin-secret'
and the Ingress 'default-sso-in-namespace-ingress'
Executing command PROCESS_DEPLOYABLE
Executing command PROCESS_DEPLOYABLE
Executing command PROCESS_DEPLOYABLE
Then a PostgreSQL DBMS Capability was provided :
Then a Red Hat SSO Capability was provided
And a database schema was prepared for the Entando App and for Component Manager
using a cluster local connection to the database Service
and the admin credentials provided in the PostgreSQL Capability's admin secret
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Red Hat SSO deployment: 'my-app-portdb-secret'
using a cluster local connection to the database Service
and the admin credentials provided in the PostgreSQL Capability's admin secret
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Red Hat SSO deployment: 'my-app-servdb-secret'
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Entando EAP deployment: 'my-app-portdb-secret'
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Entando EAP deployment: 'my-app-servdb-secret'
And a Kubernetes Deployment was created reflecting the requirements of the Entando Eap container:
using the Entando Eap Image
With a volume mounted to the standard directory /entando-data
Which is bound to a PersistentVolumeClain
And all the variables required to connect to Red Hat SSO have been configured
And the File System User/Group override 185has been applied to the mount
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Entando EAP deployment: 'my-app-portdb-secret'
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Entando EAP deployment: 'my-app-servdb-secret'
And a database schema was prepared for the Component Manager
using a cluster local connection to the database Service
and the admin credentials provided in the PostgreSQL Capability's admin secret
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Red Hat SSO deployment: 'my-app-dedb-secret'
And a Kubernetes Deployment was created reflecting the requirements of the Entando Component Manager image:
using the image 'entando/entando-component-manager'
With a volume mounted to the standard directory /entando-data
Which is bound to a PersistentVolumeClain
And all the variables required to connect to Red Hat SSO have been configured
And the File System User/Group override 185has been applied to the mount
and the credentials for the  schema user provided in a newly generated secret for the Component Manager deployment: 'my-app-dedb-secret'
And a Kubernetes Deployment was created reflecting the requirements of the AppBuilder image:
using the image 'entando/app-builder'
And all the variable required to connect to the Entando Engine has been configured
And a healthcheck path has been configured that will not trigger an authentication flow
And a Kubernetes Service was created for the Entando Engine deployment
Targeting port 8080 in the Deployment
And with a label selector matching the labels of the Pod Template on the  Deployment
And a Kubernetes Service was created for the Component Manager deployment
Targeting port 8083 in the Deployment
And with a label selector matching the labels of the Pod Template on the  Deployment
And a Kubernetes Service was created for the AppBuilder deployment
Targeting port 8081 in the Deployment
And with a label selector matching the labels of the Pod Template on the  Deployment
And a Kubernetes Ingress was created:

labels.name: feature
labels.value: As a deployer, I would like to deploy an EntandoApp directly so that I have more granular control over the configuration settings
